title: Dennis Homan
text:
Dennis Frank Homan (born January 9, 1946 in <a href="Muscle%20Shoals%2C%20Alabama">Muscle Shoals, Alabama</a>) is a former professional <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> for five seasons for the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> (1968–1970) and the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Chiefs">Kansas City Chiefs</a> (1971–1972). He later played for the <a href="Birmingham%20Americans">Birmingham Americans</a> (1974) and <a href="Birmingham%20Vulcans">Birmingham Vulcans</a> (1975) of the <a href="World%20Football%20League">World Football League</a>.
Early years.
Homan attended <a href="Muscle%20Shoals%20High%20School">Muscle Shoals High School</a> where he practiced <a href="American%20football">football</a>, <a href="basketball">basketball</a> and <a href="baseball">baseball</a>. In 2005, the Muscle Shoals City School System honored Homan by naming the field of James F. Moore Stadium, Dennis Homan Field. Homan played on the school's first <a href="American%20football">football</a> team and is the first <a href="Muscle%20Shoals%20High%20School">Muscle Shoals High School</a> player to be drafted into the <a href="NFL">NFL</a>. He also was inducted into the Colbert County Sports Hall of Fame.
He accepted a <a href="American%20football">football</a> scholarship to the <a href="University%20of%20Alabama">University of Alabama</a>, where he was a member of the 1965 National Championship team and the 1966 undefeated season. He was originally recruited as a <a href="running%20back">running back</a>. As a sophomore, he had 10 receptions for 298 yards and 4 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s. As a junior, he became a starter at <a href="split%20end">split end</a>, playing alongside <a href="Ray%20Perkins">Ray Perkins</a>, while registering 23 receptions for 377 and 5 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s.
As a senior, he was named <a href="All-American">All-American</a> and <a href="Academic%20All-American">Academic All-American</a>, after making 54 receptions for 820 yards and 9 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s. He also played in the <a href="Senior%20Bowl">Senior Bowl</a>, where he was the MVP of the South team.
During his collegiate career, he registered 87 receptions for 1,495 yards and set the school's career <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a> record with 18. In 1988, he was inducted into the Alabama Circle of Champions and in 1999, he was inducted into the Alabama Sports Hall of Fame.
Professional career.
Dallas Cowboys.
Homan was selected by the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> in the first round (20th overall) of the <a href="1968%20NFL%20Draft">1968 NFL Draft</a>. In his three years with the team, his best season came in <a href="1969%20NFL%20season">1969</a>, when he had 12 receptions for 240 yards (20 yard avg.) and no <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s. He was a member of the <a href="Super%20Bowl%20V">Super Bowl V</a> team that lost to the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Baltimore%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a>.
His preseason performances in <a href="1970%20NFL%20season">1970</a> won him the starting <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a> job over <a href="Bob%20Hayes">Bob Hayes</a> for 5 games, before Hayes regained his starting job. When troubled <a href="Lance%20Rentzel">Lance Rentzel</a> was separated from the team, Homan was passed over by former <a href="undrafted%20free%20agent">undrafted free agent</a> <a href="Reggie%20Rucker">Reggie Rucker</a> for the last two games of the regular season, the Cowboys' playoff drive and its narrow <a href="Super%20Bowl%20V">Super Bowl V</a> loss to the <a href="Baltimore%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a>. At the end of the season, he asked to be traded, so he was sent to the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Chiefs">Kansas City Chiefs</a> in exchange for <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a> <a href="Gloster%20Richardson">Gloster Richardson</a>.
Kansas City Chiefs.
Homan decided to retire after experiencing two disappointing seasons and his trade requests were not being accepted by the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Chiefs">Kansas City Chiefs</a>.
World Football League.
He returned to professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> with the <a href="Birmingham%20Americans">Birmingham Americans</a> of the <a href="World%20Football%20League">World Football League</a>, where he became one of the league's top <a href="wide%20receivers">wide receivers</a>. In 1974, he had 61 receptions for 930 yards, 8 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s and 2 action points, helping the Americans finish with a 15-5 regular season record and the <a href="World%20Football%20League">World Football League</a> championship.
In 1975, the Americans were replaced as the Birmingham <a href="World%20Football%20League">WFL</a> franchise by a new team called the <a href="Birmingham%20Vulcans">Birmingham Vulcans</a>. The <a href="World%20Football%20League">WFL</a> folded in mid-season, after he recorded 18 receptions for 277 yards, while playing in a run-oriented offense.
